<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 308, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 50 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 378, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 866, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 858, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 915, 103]]<|/det|>
In the expansion of \(\left(kx + \frac{2}{x}\right)^4\), where \(k\) is a positive constant, the term independent of \(x\) is equal to 150.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 109, 732, 133]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\) and hence determine the coefficient of \(x^2\) in the expansion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 77, 94, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 544, 98]]<|/det|>
The curve \(y = x^{2} - \frac{a}{x}\) has a stationary point at \((-3, b)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 107, 433, 127]]<|/det|>
Find the values of the constants \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[369, 81, 626, 222]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 240, 920, 314]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector of a circle, centre \(O,\) where \(OB = OC = 15 \mathrm{cm}\) . The size of angle \(BOC\) is \(\frac{2}{5}\pi\) radians. Points \(A\) and \(D\) on the lines \(OB\) and \(OC\) respectively are joined by an arc \(AD\) of a circle with centre \(O.\) The shaded region is bounded by the arcs \(AD\) and \(BC\) and by the straight lines \(AB\) and \(DC.\) It is given that the area of the shaded region is \(\frac{209}{5}\pi \mathrm{cm}^2 .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 323, 688, 343]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the shaded region. Give your answer in terms of \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 325, 917, 343]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Show that the curve with equation \(x^{2} - 3xy - 40 = 0\) and the line with equation \(3x + y + k = 0\) meet for all values of the constant \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 72, 386, 91]]<|/det|>
Circles \(C_1\) and \(C_2\) have equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 101, 737, 122]]<|/det|>
\[x^{2} + y^{2} + 6x - 10y + 18 = 0 \text{ and } (x - 9)^{2} + (y + 4)^{2} - 64 = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 220, 153]]<|/det|>
respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 559, 184]]<|/det|>
Find the distance between the centres of the circles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 504, 848, 524]]<|/det|>
\(P\) and \(Q\) are points on \(C_1\) and \(C_2\) respectively. The distance between \(P\) and \(Q\) is denoted by \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 536, 146, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 526, 555]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest and least possible values of \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 833, 95]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the region bounded by the curve and the lines \(x = 0\), \(x = \frac{7}{2}\) and \(y = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 102, 915, 121]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 710, 92]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\beta\) is an angle between \(90^{\circ}\) and \(180^{\circ}\) such that \(\sin \beta = a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 492, 123]]<|/det|>
Express \(\tan^2 \beta - 3 \sin \beta \cos \beta\) in terms of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 554, 89]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = 9x + k\) is a tangent to the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 406, 121]]<|/det|>
Find the value of the constant \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
An arithmetic progression has first term 5 and common difference \(d\), where \(d > 0\). The second, fifth and eleventh terms of the arithmetic progression, in that order, are the first three terms of a geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 311, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The sum of the first 77 terms of the arithmetic progression is denoted by \(S_{77}\). The sum of the first 10 terms of the geometric progression is denoted by \(G_{10}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 376, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(S_{77} - G_{10}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 75, 579, 94]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined by \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 3 + 6x - 2x^{2}\) for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 107, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
Express \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) in the form \(a - b(x - c)^2\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are constants, and state the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 920, 620]]<|/det|>
The graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) is transformed to the graph of \(y = \mathrm{h}(x)\) by a reflection in one of the axes followed by a translation. It is given that the graph of \(y = \mathrm{h}(x)\) has a minimum point at the origin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 632, 579, 651]]<|/det|>
Give details of the reflection and translation involved.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 632, 920, 651]]<|/det|>
